params.text:
Adding your model to the Pi

We now have our trained model, we just need a way to run it. We can do this by adding our new model to the Pi and running it the same way we ran the existing model. To do this:

1. Open cyberduck and drag-n-drop the unzipped model folder you downloaded from the teachable machine website into the 'models' file. Make sure the name of the folder represents your model so you can easily identify it later on.

2. Open PuTTY and SSH into the Pi. Go inside the pi_camera_detection directory and type the following command:

nano predict.py

Find the part where the models are defined. It is a list of tuples. Add a new tuple to the end of the list with a name for your model and the directory it is stored in, for example

models = [fdafsd
          ("New Model", "new_model/")]

Now you can run the prediction program and test out your new model.

tipsAndFeedback.tip: Make sure you moved the right folder into Cyberduck. Delete the current folder and drag-n-drop the unzipped folder you downloaded from teachable machine into the models folder. Check that both files are inside.

Locate the unzipped folder you downloaded from teachable machine, if you can only find the zip file then right-click the file and select 'extract all'. Go to Cyberduck and open the models folder located in the pi_camera_detection folder, then drag-n-drop the unzipped folder inside.

params.question: On Cyberduck, when you open the Pi's models folder, is your new model's folder there? Does it contain two files called 'model.tflite' and 'labels.txt'?

metadata.title: Adding your model to the Pi
metadata.extraTitle: Adding your model to the Pi

params.text:
Running your model

To run the new model, type the following command into the terminal:

python predict.py

It will prompt you to select a model to run. If the new model was added correctly to the Pi, then the new model will be in the list of options. Type the number corresponding to the new model into the terminal and press enter.

Your new model should now be running!
